history.content:
First of all, it is great that as a transfer student you want to be ambitious and take 189. Good for you. (Remember, 189 is also labeled 289A and it is a true mezzanine course even for Berkeley students --- suitable for advanced undergrads or grad students in their first couple of years.) Take 126 and 127. They will get your probability and optimization knowledge, as well as mathematical maturity, up to the level where you will be able to understand 189 and internalize key ML concepts.

If you don't feel ready for 126, then you are certainly not ready for 189. If you can't reach 189 in the limited time you have and just get through 126 and 127, then good for you. You are far ahead of the pack. You'll have picked up the most important set of skills and can either take a 189 type course as a grad student, or read through the 189 notes and other reference material to self-teach yourself the material. There are a ton of tutorials and blog posts and the like out there on the operational side of ML, and with a solid 126/127 background, those should be easy to digest. You should also be able to engage with ML textbooks at that point.

The goal of an undergrad degree isn't to teach you everything you will need to know. It is to build you a foundation so that you can keep learning through your lifetime.

children.subject:
Mudit, I am trying to be encouraging. It is not about skills. Transfers are great and strong Berkeley students. The problem is only the extremely short runway that the system gives them. 5 semesters is an incredibly short period of time. And so, being able to schedule ambitiously to hit an intro grad level course before graduating is way harder than it is for someone who has an 8 semester runway. There's just not as much room to maneuver. This is a reality that many forget. Effectively, every transfer is asked to graduate in 2.5 years. It's not impossible, but the fact that so many transfer students pull this off doesn't take away from the fact that they are a very ambitious and hardworking group. (Ambition isn't graded on a curve.)

It is great that more folks are interested in machine learning. This is literally why the entire curriculum has been reworked with the introduction of 16AB to better support this, and to make it clear that these ideas are considered fundamental to *everyone* in the major. Given that *every* major has significant exposure to linear regression, polynomial features, matching pursuit and sparse recovery, the SVD, k-means, PCA, and classification by hyperplanes before they even leave the lower division; it's not like they don't know anything about machine learning. By the time they have also taken 126 and 127, they *already* know more machine learning than most students anywhere else in a traditional EE or traditional CS program who have taken an ML course. Getting 189-level depth and perspective on top of this puts students in a *far* better position than most. (In fact, it largely obviates the need for many students to pursue a traditional course-only MS elsewhere.)

+1 for Mudit's comment. As another transfer, the tone of the initial statement by Prof Sahai didn't come off right. While I understood the actual content in the full instructor response (and as a side note, I do appreciate Prof Sahai's active presence on Piazza), I would kindly ask that future statements be phrased differently.

Professor Sahai -- perhaps this isn't obvious to you, but your statement "First of all, it is great that as a transfer student you want to be ambitious and take 189. Good for you." comes across as quite patronizing. Today, I found that 60-70% of all graduate student applications in Berkeley EECS have been for ML recently. Given the popularity of the field, I don't think it's surprising that everyone is interested in taking 189. Your recommendations for taking 126 and 127 first are well understood, but it's too condescending to make blanket statements about the skill levels of all transfer students regarding whether or not they are prepared to take 189. 

@OP -- please don't be discouraged from at least trying to follow the course, 126 and 127 or not. The course materials are availble on eecs189.org. While it mght be challenging given that you find your background to be weak, you can still read the notes and looking up things you don't understand.

history.content:
HELLO!

I'm a transfer student in my final year of studies in CS. I have 2 semesters left.

I'd like to take CS189 next semester but have realized that my math and probability background is super weak.

I know it's recommended that we take EE126 and EE127 before CS189, but b/c I have just this semester and the next, I'm considering taking STAT134 to bolster my understanding in the probability section taught in CS70, before taking 189 next spring. I honestly don't feel ready for ee126. 

Yay or nay? Or are there better classes out there to make me better prepared at the level I am at?
history.subject: yet another question about cs189
